Award.AwardTitle: EAGER: Development of a Forensic Pollen Database and Climate Modeling Platform
Award.AbstractNarration:
This project uses funds, under the auspices of the EArly Concept Grant For Exploratory Research (EAGER) award concept, to assist in the development of a new biogeographic tool that uses pollen as a geo-locational marker for the probable origin of a suite of pollen in a sample.

Such a tool would allow pollen analysts to generate paleoclimate data in a far easier and more consistent way than ever before and allow for expansion of basic research in pollen and climate analysis thereby enabling accurate, reproducible, and precise ecological and geographical information regarding the provenance of a pollen sample.

The researcher aims to build a complete and advanced palynological database, called POLCLIM for pollen-climate, for Neotropical and subtropical pollen. The database would be publically available and enable the identification of important pollen taxa in a comprehensive geo-relational database of pollen types, distributional metadata, and probabilities of co-occurrence.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Pollen grains can usually be identified to family, often to genus and occasionally to species. Gaining information about pollen identities is of use in the study of allergens, climate change, forensic science and in the search for oil and gas. South and central America is important in all these contexts and is also one of the systems with highest biodiversity on the planet. An initial analysis suggested that the pollen of c. 3500 genera might be resolvable using light microscopy.   

 

In this project we constructed a pollen database that contains 5000 types representing about 3500 genera, of herbarium vouchered specimens, prepared, imaged and described under standardized protocols. Z-stack videos in addition to high-resolution photographic images of grains in multiple orientations are included. A multiple entry key provides a user-friendly interface to assist in identifying pollen types. Maps of the distribution of genera are also provided as are models of the possible range of the species beyond the locations of actual collection.

 

We used expert opinion to prioritize families and genera for inclusion in this project, deliberately omitting families where a genus level identification was not possible or families whose pollen does not preserve. The projects primary sponsor was the Department of Homeland Security and they have prohibited public release of the database or a detailed description of it.
